Hi :)

I still didnt find a solution to this problem.
Can it be the problem that I am using Heritrix 3.1.1?
Is it possible that JVM or server settings are causing Heritrix to use 
just one queue?

so just in case this might be the cause.....here are my current JVM 
settings:

export JAVA_OPTS="
-Xms3072m
-Xmx19000m
-XX:NewSize=256m
-XX:SurvivorRatio=1
-XX:TargetSurvivorRatio=2
-XX:MaxTenuringThreshold=3
-XX:+UseConcMarkSweepGC
-XX:+CMSScavengeBeforeRemark
-XX:PretenureSizeThreshold=256m
-XX:CMSFullGCsBeforeCompaction=1
-XX:+UseCMSInitiatingOccupancyOnly
-XX:CMSInitiatingOccupancyFraction=70
-XX:CMSTriggerPermRatio=80
-XX:CMSMaxAbortablePrecleanTime=6000
-XX:+CMSConcurrentMTEnabled
-XX:+UseParNewGC
-XX:ConcGCThreads=4
-XX:ParallelGCThreads=8"


Thanks,
Markus


On 26.08.2014 11:55, 'Markus.Mirsberger' markus.mirsberger@... 
[archive-crawler] wrote:
> On 26.08.2014 03:54, Gordon Mohr gojomo@... [archive-crawler] wrote:
>> On 8/25/14, 12:42 AM, 'Markus.Mirsberger' markus.mirsberger@...
>> [archive-crawler] wrote:
>>> I already set parallelQueues to 20 before but this didn't increase the
>>> number of active queues/threads as you could see.
>> Hmm. That should be the only change necessary: from that point on, if
>> you're using one of the standard QueueAssignmentPolicies, any URIs
>> discovered on a single site should be scattered over 20 queues instead
>> of 1. Unlike your prior stats snapshot showing only 1 queue with
>> millions of URIs, you'd then see 20 queues.
>>
>> Was 'parallelQueues' set to a higher value from the very beginning of
>> the crawl? Once a URI is sent to a queue, changing this setting
>> mid-crawl doesn't cause any immediate change. The URI still needs to
>> come off its original queue, one at a time. Then, depending on the
>> 'deferToPrevious' setting, it might get processed without reconsidering
>> its queue (deferToPrevious=true), or be immediately re-evaluated
>> (deferToPrevious=false) and thus potentially re-enqueued rather than
>> fetched.
> Yes 'parallelQueues' was set to 20 at the very beginning of the crawl.
> This is my basic setting in the profile Iam using for every Crawl.
> The same for 'deferToPrevious' ... this was set to 'false' at the beginning.
> Just to be sure this might not be the reason for my problem. I am still
> using Heritrix 3.1.1
>
>>> What I did now was setting deferToPrevious to "true". At least this
>>> increased the number of parallel threads to 2-3.
>>> But I still dont get more than 4kb/sec :(
>> That sounds exactly backwards. If deferToPrevious=true, you'll get
>> *less* reassignment-among-queues and thus less long-run speedup. Only
>> new URIs being discovered will get spread over 20 queues.
>>
>> Note, though, that with deferToPrevious=false, and changing
>> parallelQueues mid-crawl, there is often then a tight busy-loop as
>> 19-out-of-each-20 URIs on the original single queue pop off and *don't*
>> get crawled, but instead get reenqueued over other queues. This might
>> stick out as a period of higher CPU and local IO usage, without much (or
>> any) fetch speedup. However, as the giant queue shrinks rapidly, and
>> other queues grow, you should then start to see a higher request rate
>> over time, approaching the 20x speedup (if there aren't other CPU/IO
>> bottlenecks).
>>
>> So you'd want to give the deferToPrevious=false setting some time to
>> have its effect on queue-distribution.
> As I mentioned in the comment before ... deferToPrevious was set to
> false at the beginning of the crawl and I ended up with only one queue.
>>> I think it is not necessary to use sheets in my case. I crawl every
>>> domain in an own crawljob and dont allow the job to crawl other domains.
>> There were 14 other empty queues in your stats cut-and-paste... just be
>> aware when rerunning this crawl, if a global parallelQueues=20 setting
>> is in effect, they'll all be equally hammered.
> Yes I am aware this. Every Job is crawling only one single domain by
> request of the domain's owner. So the speed of the crawl will be
> adjusted in agreement with the owner.
> And both the crawling server and the server with the domain on it are
> almost sleeping and definitly not the bottlenecks here ... maybe if I
> ever make all the queues really running parallel :)
>
> Thanks,
> Markus
>
>> - Gordon
>>
>>> Regards,
>>> Markus
>>>
>>> On 25.08.2014 13:32, Gordon Mohr gojomo@... [archive-crawler] wrote:
>>>> The core politeness assumptions of Heritrix have been that URIs for a
>>>> single 'site' should go into a single logical queue, and that only one
>>>> URI should be in process from any one queue at a time.
>>>>
>>>> That's what you're running into, even after minimizing the other
>>>> politeness delays between fetches.
>>>>
>>>> If you're sure that more-aggressive crawling is alright (as seems to be
>>>> the case with your target site with owner permission), you can cause the
>>>> usual queue-assignment to instead distribute a single site's URIs over
>>>> many related queues. Then, if (for example) using 5 queues, 5 requests
>>>> can be in process in parallel, resulting in up to 5X faster crawling.
>>>>
>>>> The relevant setting is 'parallelQueues' on the QueueAssignmentPolicy.
>>>> See some notes here:
>>>>
>>>> https://webarchive.jira.com/wiki/display/Heritrix/H3+Dev+Notes+for+Crawl+Operators#H3DevNotesforCrawlOperators-QueueAssignmentPolicies:%27parallelQueues%27and%27deferToPrevious%27settings
>>>>
>>>> As it's usually the case that you want most sites to be crawled in the
>>>> normal polite manner, even when there are one or more sites that can be
>>>> crawled more aggressively, it often makes sense to only set a higher
>>>> 'parallelQueues' value in a "sheet override" to affect some subset of
>>>> sites. Thus, that's one of the example overridden settings in the sheets
>>>> example at:
>>>>
>>>> https://webarchive.jira.com/wiki/display/Heritrix/Sheets
>>>>
>>>> - Gordon
>>>>
>>>> On 8/24/14, 5:14 AM, 'Markus.Mirsberger' markus.mirsberger@...
